Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: DAWN2 - What's Next for LIGO?
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the 11 February 2016 announcement by LIGO of the detection of GW150914, the era of gravitational wave astronomy has now passed a historical threshold. LIGO's first gravitational wave event opens new avenues for astrophysical exploration and data analysis enhancements informed by direct detection. It should be recalled that the detectors that brought LIGO to success were first conceived almost a quarter century ago. Thus equally importantly, now is the time to start to plan how (and where) to build more sensitive third-generation detectors to probe the gravitational wave Universe to higher redshift. This award supports a workshop entitled "DAWN2: What's Next for LIGO?" which will address this need by exploring the prospects for advancing the field over the next several years and identifying the necessary groundwork for designing and implementing the next generation of detectors. This forum will be informed by insights gained by LIGO, the LIGO Scientific Collaboration and astrophysical partners from the first detections. Participants will discuss how these first few detections might inform which paths offer the best opportunities forward, and how the community should begin to develop plans for the international network of second and third generation instruments.

The workshop will be held at the Georgia Institute of Technology on July 7-8, 2016. The workshop will have three sessions, one for each of the following topics: Advanced LIGO in the near and long term future, the international detector network and Multi-messenger astronomy, long term planning by the international community for 3rd generation detectors. The workshop will have three sessions, one for each of the topics listed above, each chaired by one of the members of the scientific organizing committee. Each topic will be introduced by "vision" talks from different points of view, which will be followed by a break and an hour of discussion time, generally freeform but moderated by a panel consisting of that session's speakers plus one or two others. After the meeting, the panelists will capture the ideas and consensus views that are brought forth by the presenters and the following discussion, and record them in one or more white papers. In this way, it is hoped that a clearer vision will take shape for ways to improve the scientific potential of the LIGO detectors. This should help the community focus on key technical developments and initiatives with existing and new resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With LIGO's detection of GW150914 and GW151226, the era of gravitational wave astronomy has passed an historical threshold, opening new avenues for astrophysical exploration and data analysis enhancements informed by the direct detection of gravitational waves. The detectors that brought LIGO to success were first conceived almost a quarter century ago, so now is the time to start to plan how and where to build more sensitive third-generation detectors to probe the gravitational wave Universe to higher redshift. 

This award supported a workshop entitled “DAWN2: What’s Next for LIGO?”, which addressed this need by exploring the prospects for advancing the field over the next several years and identifying the groundwork for designing and implementing the next generation of detectors.  The workshop took place on July 7-8, 2016 at the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, GA. Discussions in the meeting were informed by the insights gained by LIGO, the LIGO Scientific Collaboration and astrophysical partners from the first detections. Participants, including international partners and astronomers, explored how the first few detections might inform which paths offer the best opportunities forward, and how the community should begin to develop plans for the international network of second and third generation instruments. Discussion at the workshop led to the formulation of key recommendation on three focus areas.

1. Advanced LIGO in the near and long term future. The experimental community has begun exploring possible upgrades to Advanced LIGO (A+). The A+ upgrade is a high priority, near-term goal once Advanced LIGO has achieved its design sensitivity and has carried out a long duration observing run.  Participants endorsed the current A+ design, highlighted a strong scientific rationale for implementing the A+ upgrade on LIGO-India before it begins science operations, and emphasized that continued focus on improving coating thermal noise is essential for all future gravitational-wave detectors.

2. The international detector network and multi-messenger astronomy. The localization of the first few gravitational wave events, necessary to enable the search for electromagnetic counterparts, will unavoidably remain poor until advanced Virgo will join the network. Speeding the growth and robustness of the international detector network will be a priority in the next decade. For this, the community should identify a set of performance metrics for future planning and prioritize detector improvements when planning commissioning breaks, upgrades, and observing runs, keeping the science potential as a target at all times.  The workshop highlighted that tighter R&D coordination among the major projects is beneficial to future detector development, with allocation of sufficient funding, coordinated at both the agency and the project levels. Achieving comparable sensitivities requires investments from multiple agencies, as well as advocacy from the community with a strong, compelling science case, reaching out beyond the borders of the GW community, to astronomers, cosmologists, geophysicists, materials scientists. In particular, regarding electromagnetic followup, workshop participants endorsed more rapid communication of all GW information available, including sky maps, significance, distance and event type, as well as continuing the practice of memoranda of understanding for focused science targets and papers, even in the era of open triggers.

3. Long term planning by the international community for 3rd generation detectors. The detection of gravitational waves with LIGO detectors has capped a large effort by scientists and funding agencies in building large scale, high precision instruments for a new form of astrophysical observations. To go forward with new facilities will require a worldwide effort to understand the scientific opportunities and to coordinate internationally the determination of the optimal designs, numbers, and locations of such facilities. Lessons learned from past international efforts like the Einstein Telescope and the International Linear Collider formed the basis of this discussion. 

Following the workshop, focus panels summarized the discussions and wrote up conclusions and key outcomes in a report that will serve as a basis for a future roadmap for the field going beyond the current generation of detectors.
